sentences: Damage were a British R&B boy band who achieved success in the 1990s with eleven hit singles, including four top 10 successes on the UK Singles Chart.
The band sent a demo tape of a cover version of the Jackson 5 song "Anything" to Jazz Summers of Big Life Records in early 1995.
The band sent a demo tape of a cover version of the Jackson 5 song "Anything" to Jazz Summers of Big Life Records in early 1995.
Damage made inroads into the UK Singles Chart and the second single "Love II Love" reached number 12 while the follow-up, "Forever", charted at number 6 during the Christmas period.
Damage's debut album Forever followed in 1997, along with two further UK top 10 singles – "Love Guaranteed" and a cover version of Eric Clapton's "Wonderful Tonight", the latter reaching number 3.

sentences: In 2000, they signed with Cooltempo Records and released the second album's first single, "Ghetto Romance".

sentences: On 30 August, "Rumours" was released as second single.

sentences: The second album was initially due for release on 25 September 2000, following the release of "Rumours".

sentences: The initial track listing includes the tracks "Feelin' Me" and "Midnight Caller", as well as an outro called "Before We Leave".

sentences: The second album, Since You've Been Gone, was released on 2 April 2001.

sentences: In August, after the third and fourth singles – "Still Be Lovin' You" and "So What If I" – Richards decided to leave the band.
section: == History == | === 2000–2001: Since You've Been Gone and split ===

sentences: The four members released "After the Love Has Gone" as the fifth and final single and decided to split in December 2001.

sentences: Harriott and Jones formed CherryBlackStone in 2002, but the duo lasted only a few months.

sentences: Damage performed a one-off gig at Party in the Park in Leeds on 25 July 2010, but did not officially reunite at that time.
section: == History == | === 2000–2001: Since You've Been Gone and split ===

sentences: 2014–present: Return =

In early 2014, Damage reformed as a quartet without Richards for the second series of the ITV2 documentary The Big Reunion along with other groups such as Eternal and A1, although Richards did appear on the show to talk about the band and meet with his bandmates one last time.
